title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION: The Consumer Credit Protection Act is amended to include provisions for protecting financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act includes provisions for protecting customer information of financial institutions. It defines terms such as "customer" and "customer information of a financial institution." The Financial Information Privacy Act defines customer information as any data held by a financial institution related to the customer's relationship with the institution. Financial institutions encompass entities providing financial services to customers with accounts or relationships, including depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. Sec. 1003 of the Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as making false statements or representations. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define the term 'financial institution' for this purpose. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits disclosing customer information from a financial institution through false statements or representations to deceive officers, employees, or customers. This includes providing forged, counterfeit, or fraudulent documents to obtain the information. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits the use of forged, counterfeit, or fraudulent documents to deceive financial institution officers, employees, or agents into releasing customer information. It is also a violation to solicit someone to obtain customer information under false pretenses. Law enforcement agencies are exempt from these provisions when obtaining customer information for official duties. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows law enforcement agencies to obtain customer information from financial institutions for official duties. Financial institutions are also allowed to access customer information for security testing, misconduct investigations, and information recovery. The Financial Information Privacy Act permits law enforcement agencies to access customer information from financial institutions for official purposes. The Act also allows financial institutions to retrieve customer information obtained by others and enforces compliance through the Federal Trade Commission or other agencies when necessary. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows law enforcement agencies to access customer information from financial institutions. Compliance with the Act is enforced by the Federal Trade Commission or other agencies when needed. Compliance with the Collection Practices Act is enforced by specific agencies for different types of banks. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows law enforcement agencies to access customer information from financial institutions. Compliance with the Act is enforced by various agencies, including the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for different types of banks. Violations of the Act are treated as violations of other laws by the respective regulatory agencies. The National Credit Union Administration enforces compliance with the Financial Information Privacy Act. Violations of the Act are treated as violations of other laws by regulatory agencies. States also have authority to take action against violations of the Act. The State can take legal action against violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act, including seeking injunctions, recovering damages, and being awarded costs and attorney fees. Federal regulators must be notified before any state action is taken. The State must provide prior written notice to the Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies before taking legal action under the Financial Information Privacy Act. The FTC and agencies have the right to intervene in the action and be heard on all matters. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows the Federal Trade Commission and relevant agencies to intervene in legal actions, be heard on all matters, remove actions to the appropriate US district court, and file petitions for appeal. State law enforcement officers can still conduct investigations and compel witnesses or evidence. Federal actions take precedence over state actions. The Financial Information Privacy Act grants the Federal Trade Commission and related agencies the authority to take civil action for violations. States are prohibited from taking action against defendants named in federal complaints during pending federal actions. Non-compliance with the Act may result in liability for actual damages to financial institutions or customers. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows for civil action for violations, with penalties including actual damages, additional damages, and attorneys' fees. Criminal penalties for violating section 1003 include fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases. Section 1003 of the Financial Information Privacy Act imposes fines or imprisonment up to 5 years for violations. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving over $100,000 in illegal activity within a 12-month period. Section 1007 clarifies that state laws are not superseded unless inconsistent with federal provisions. Section 1008 of the Financial Information Privacy Act requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to assist depository institutions in preventing prohibited activities. Additionally, a report evaluating the effectiveness of the remedies provided in the Act must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of enactment. The General, in consultation with relevant agencies, must report to Congress on the effectiveness of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and make recommendations for further legislative or regulatory actions to protect financial privacy.
